descriptionSet.description: An advertisement for Lux Toilet Soap image has a blonde woman, wearing a strapless top, and holding a white bar of soap in her left hand.

inscription.text: The beauty soap of the film stars LUX TOILET SOAP

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: The beauty soap of the film stars LUX TOILET SOAP
text-en: 001011 1
text-en: LEVER BROTHERS (INDIA) LIMITED
description-en: An advertisement for Lux Toilet Soap image has a blonde woman, wearing a strapless top, and holding a white bar of soap in her left hand. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: It is hard to imagine that an Indian Women could be depicted on an advertisement in such a seductive way back then, not even if the woman could have been identified as a movie star. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: One of the longest running campaigns the world over, Lux, an international venture of Lever Brothers, featured Hollywood stars in most parts of the world. This is not surprising since Hollywood was the only global film industry at the time. Lux entered India in 1929 and while its early advertisements would feature Hollywood actresses, they would eventually be replaced almost completely by local stars. (Sabeena Gadihoke)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Marked by its use of the portraiture of known faces, Lux can be seen as one of the earliest forms of celebrity endorsements. As an extra cinematic site that showcased female stardom for its consumers, the repetitive advertisement could also be situated within practices of cinephilia. (Sabeena Gadihoke)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Surprisingly in early years Lux would target a vernacular public using the same imagery! The reverse of the Lux advertisement reproduced here, and featuring a rather risqué image of presumably a "foreign actress". (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)
related literature: Dyer, Richard and Christine Gledhill 2009. "Wanted: Cultured ladies Only! Female Stardom and Cinema in India 1930s-1950s". Urbana and Chicago: University of Illinois Press. (gs)
related literature: Gadihoke, Sabika 2010. "Selling Soap and Stardom: The Story of Lux" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/104/index.html (9.12.2010)(gs)
related literature: McClintock, Anne 2001. “Soft Soaping Empire: Commodity Racism and Imperial Advertising” in Double Crossings: Madness, Sexuality and Imperialism. Vancouver, Canada: Ronsdale. (gs)
related literature: Sivulka, Julianne 1998. "Soap, Sex and Cigarettes: A Cultural History of Advertising". Belmont, California: Wadsworth Publishing Co. (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Blonde hair is in most cases a distinctive visual marker on advertising images for being Western and therefore an exclusive marker for whiteness. (la)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Many Indian actresses, too, were featured in Indian advertisements for Lux Soap. From Madhuri Dixit and Hema Malini to Aishwarya Rai, Kareena Kapoor and Kathrina Kaif. It seems as if Lux had and still has a big share of the Indian soap market. A nice overview of Lux vintage ads featuring Indian actresses can be found under http://8ate.blogspot.com/2009/09/vintage-lux-ads-beauty-soap-of-film.html .(la)
related hyperlinks: http://8ate.blogspot.com/2009/09/vintage-lux-ads-beauty-soap-of-film.html last accessed 2012-03-29 (la/ja)

related literature: Loyo, Hilaria 2007. "Blinding Blondes: Whiteness, Femininity, and Stardom." In W.Everett (Ed.): Questions of Colour in Cinema, Frankfurt/M etc.: Peter Lang: 179-196. (la)
